headshotImage.caption: AR McBrine headshot
headshotImage.longCaption: AR McBrine headshot

dismissalComment.html: loud appeal, or celebrappeal, from Shamsi, and he's given lbw but Ireland review! McBrine went for the reverse sweep, got hit just under the knee roll right in front of middle and off. UltraEdge shows there's no bat, we all wait for ball-tracking, and it finally says it's pitched in line and is "hitting". So Shamsi gets the wicket after conceding two boundaries and Ireland lose a wicket and review

headshotImage.caption: AR McBrine headshot
headshotImage.longCaption: AR McBrine headshot

dismissalText.commentary: Rassie van der Dussen lbw b McBrine 49 (70b 2x4 0x6 87m) SR: 70

dismissalComment.html: loud, loud appeal for lbw, the appeal is dying and then the finger goes up! van der Dussen reviews immediately, what a big wicket this will be even if it's umpire's call. He is struck in front of middle and leg on the back foot after the ball turns inland goes past the bat, not much in the batter's favour so far. They're checking for the edge now, and it appears there's a very very thin spike when the ball passes the bat. The umpire is having a look at it again and again. Rock and roll, again and again. "Roll it once more, just once more slowly," says the third umpire. "No contact with bat and ball," he concludes, and then ball-tracking shows it's clipping leg stump, which means the on-field decision stays. van der Dussen goes for 49 and SA four down all of a sudden

dismissalComment.html: but this edge is taken, straightforward chance for the keeper! Outside off with the angle, Little has been coming around the wicket to Verreynne, the batter throws his hands with a big swing and gets a faint outside edge for the keeper. He throws the ball in celebration, Little is pumped as well. They know they're getting closer

dismissalText.commentary: Kagiso Rabada run out (Campher/Tucker) 16 (12b 0x4 2x6 19m) SR: 133.33

dismissalComment.html: swung away to deep square leg, but what really is happening? Is that caught? Was that a no-ball? Or was there a run-out? It was a full-toss on middle and off, and looked pretty high as Maharaj pulled off the front foot. And an above-waist no-ball is called. Umpires await to check out the run-out drama now. The ball was cracked to deep square leg, who caught the ball but threw it back to the keeper, who blew away the bails while Rabada was out of the crease after running to the keeper's end while the ball was in the air. The fielder took the catch cleanly, yet threw the ball back, perhaps realising that it could be an above-waist no-ball, which it was in the end. And a run-out at the keeper's end is confirmed. Though it was a no-ball, as per rules, a batter can be run-out off it. Phew! Too much happening there. Rabada perhaps assumed that because it would be a no-ball, the ball would have been dead the moment it was caught. Anyway, he has to walk off now

commentTextItems.html: yorker, hits leg stump and game over. Nortje moves across his stumps, but this is an inswinging yorker on middle, as the batter gets an inside edge on to the leg stump to finish it off

commentPostTextItems.html: Ireland take a 1-0 lead in the series with one match to go - the first was a washout - and South Africa must now win the final ODI to not lose the series. A complete all-round display from the hosts means the visitors are comfortably beaten. South Africa will have much to ponder about after this loss: they had no control with the ball at the death, they dropped four catches and their batters could never take off. But join us for the final match of the series in three days' time. Until then, it's a goodbye from Binoy, Vishal and me, Himanshu!
Prashan W: "Congratulations and well done Ireland from a Sri Lankan fan."

Balbirnie, the Ireland captain, is also the Player of the Match: "Extremely proud. Put in on a greenish wicket. It was a tough wicket to take wickets on. It was a win we needed as a team. Really proud of the lads. We outfielded them, which made the difference. We need such efforts to beat these nations. Huge day for cricket in Ireland. We'll have a couple of beers and enjoy. But at the same time, we are hungry to win the series.
"[Exciting] to face players of that calibre, and get a decent score is great. We had a really bad series in the Netherlands, and we are really pushing that to get the [Super League] points."

Here's Bavuma after the game: "I wouldn't think we took it lightly [by resting de Kock and Ngidi]. There's a lot for us to work on, well done to them. Plan in the first powerplay was to take wickets. Our fielding let us down. Momentum was always on their side. No partnerships of significance except the one between Janneman and Rassie."
Josh Bone: "Look at that bowling card. The definition of a team effort"
Vrushabh Shetty: "My word IRELAND have outclassed SOUTH AFRICA "
justin smyth: "Yes, Yes, Yes, what a way to finish it. Stumps get knocked over and Ireland win. A massive 10 points for us!"

6.20pm So Ireland win by 43 runs, and beat South Africa for the first time in an ODI, with the sides yet to clash in any other format. A huge, morale-boosting win for the hosts, who posted 290 after being inserted by the visitors. They raked up runs at will at the death, and hit with the ball each time it mattered. Credit to Balbirnie, Dockrell and Tector for setting up with the bat, before all the bowlers chipped in to contribute.

dismissalText.commentary: Kagiso Rabada run out (Campher/Tucker) 16 (12b 0x4 2x6 19m) SR: 133.33

commentTextItems.html: swung away to deep square leg, but what really is happening? Is that caught? Was that a no-ball? Or was there a run-out? It was a full-toss on middle and off, and looked pretty high as Maharaj pulled off the front foot. And an above-waist no-ball is called. Umpires await to check out the run-out drama now. The ball was cracked to deep square leg, who caught the ball but threw it back to the keeper, who blew away the bails while Rabada was out of the crease after running to the keeper's end while the ball was in the air. The fielder took the catch cleanly, yet threw the ball back, perhaps realising that it could be an above-waist no-ball, which it was in the end. And a run-out at the keeper's end is confirmed. Though it was a no-ball, as per rules, a batter can be run-out off it. Phew! Too much happening there. Rabada perhaps assumed that because it would be a no-ball, the ball would have been dead the moment it was caught. Anyway, he has to walk off now
full-toss on middle and leg, driven on the up to long-on

commentPreTextItems.html: Neville Smeda: "20 years ago, SA being 7 wickets down needing 12 an over still made them favorites to win because Pollock, Klusener, Boucher, Boje, Symcox, etc would be at the crease! Miss those times."

dismissalText.commentary: Rassie van der Dussen lbw b McBrine 49 (70b 2x4 0x6 87m) SR: 70

dismissalComment.html: loud, loud appeal for lbw, the appeal is dying and then the finger goes up! van der Dussen reviews immediately, what a big wicket this will be even if it's umpire's call. He is struck in front of middle and leg on the back foot after the ball turns inland goes past the bat, not much in the batter's favour so far. They're checking for the edge now, and it appears there's a very very thin spike when the ball passes the bat. The umpire is having a look at it again and again. Rock and roll, again and again. "Roll it once more, just once more slowly," says the third umpire. "No contact with bat and ball," he concludes, and then ball-tracking shows it's clipping leg stump, which means the on-field decision stays. van der Dussen goes for 49 and SA four down all of a sudden

dismissalText.commentary: Kagiso Rabada run out (Campher/Tucker) 16 (12b 0x4 2x6 19m) SR: 133.33

dismissalComment.html: swung away to deep square leg, but what really is happening? Is that caught? Was that a no-ball? Or was there a run-out? It was a full-toss on middle and off, and looked pretty high as Maharaj pulled off the front foot. And an above-waist no-ball is called. Umpires await to check out the run-out drama now. The ball was cracked to deep square leg, who caught the ball but threw it back to the keeper, who blew away the bails while Rabada was out of the crease after running to the keeper's end while the ball was in the air. The fielder took the catch cleanly, yet threw the ball back, perhaps realising that it could be an above-waist no-ball, which it was in the end. And a run-out at the keeper's end is confirmed. Though it was a no-ball, as per rules, a batter can be run-out off it. Phew! Too much happening there. Rabada perhaps assumed that because it would be a no-ball, the ball would have been dead the moment it was caught. Anyway, he has to walk off now

headshotImage.longCaption: Rassie van der Dussen player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalComment.html: loud, loud appeal for lbw, the appeal is dying and then the finger goes up! van der Dussen reviews immediately, what a big wicket this will be even if it's umpire's call. He is struck in front of middle and leg on the back foot after the ball turns inland goes past the bat, not much in the batter's favour so far. They're checking for the edge now, and it appears there's a very very thin spike when the ball passes the bat. The umpire is having a look at it again and again. Rock and roll, again and again. "Roll it once more, just once more slowly," says the third umpire. "No contact with bat and ball," he concludes, and then ball-tracking shows it's clipping leg stump, which means the on-field decision stays. van der Dussen goes for 49 and SA four down all of a sudden
